chapter.title: KSB Parameters
chapter.para: Here is a comprehensive set of configuration parameters used to configure the Kuali Service Bus.

section.title: serviceServletUrl
section.para: The URL that resolves to the KSB servlet that handles incoming requests from the service bus. All services exported onto the service bus use this value to construct their endpoint URLs when they are published to the service registry. See section below on configuring the KSBDispatcherServlet. This parameter should point to the absolute URL of where that servlet is mapped. It should include a trailing slash.

section.title: application.id
section.para: An identifier that indicates the name of the logical node on the service bus. If the application is running in a cluster, this should be the same for each machine in the cluster. This is used for namespacing of services, among other things. All services exported from the client application onto the service bus use this value as their default namespace unless otherwise specified.

section.title: keystore.file, keystore.alias, keystore.password
section.para: See the documentation below on keystore management.

section.title: ksb.mode
section.para: Mode in which to load the KSB module. Valid values are local and embedded. There is currently no difference in how the KSB module loads based on these settings. It will always try to load the KSB struts module if a KualiActionServlet is configured.

section.title: ksb.url
section.para: The URL of the KSB web application screens

section.title: rice.ksb.struts.config.files
section.para: The file that defines the struts context for the KRice KSB struts module. The struts module is loaded automatically if a KualiActionServlet is configured in the web.xml.

section.title: dev.mode
section.para: Indicates whether this node should export and consume services from the entire service bus. If set to false, then the machine will not register its services in the global service registry. Instead, it can only consume services that it has available locally. In addition to this, other nodes on the service bus will not be able to "see" this node and will therefore not forward any messages to it.

section.title: message.persistence
section.para: If true, then messages will be persisted to the datastore. Otherwise, they will only be stored in memory. If message persistence is not turned on and the server is shutdown while there are still messages that need to be sent, those messages will be lost. For a production environment, it is recommended that message persistence be set to true.

section.title: message.delivery
section.para: Can be set to either synchronous or async. If this is set to synchronous, then messages that are sent in an asynchronous fashion using the KSB API will instead be sent synchronously. This is useful in certain development and unit testing scenarios. For a production environment, it is recommended that message delivery be set to async.

section.title: message.off
section.para: If set to true then asynchronous messages will not be sent. In the case that message persistence is turned on, they will be persisted in the message store and can even be picked up later using the Message Fetcher. However, if message persistence is turned off, these messages will be lost. This can be useful in certain debugging or testing scenarios.

section.title: RouteQueue.maxRetryAttempts
section.para: Sets the default number of retries that will be executed if a message fails to be sent. This retry count can also be customized for a specific service. (See Exposing Services on the Bus)

section.title: RouteQueue.timeIncrement
section.para: Sets the default time increment between retry attempts. As with RouteQueue.maxRetryAttempts this can also be configured at the service level.

section.title: RouteQueue.maxRetryAttemptsOverride
section.para: If set with a number, it will temporarily set the retry attempts for ALL services going into exception routing. A good way to prevent all messages in a node that is having trouble from making it to exception routing is by setting the number arbitrarily high. The message.off param does the same thing.

section.title: Routing.ImmediateExceptionRouting
section.para: If set to true, then messages that fail to be sent will not be re-tried. Instead their MessageExceptionHandler will be invoked immediately.

section.title: useQuartzDatabase
section.para: When using the embedded Quartz scheduler started by the KSB, indicates whether that Quartz scheduler should store its entries in the database. If this is true, then the appropriate Quartz properties should be set as well (see ksb.org.quartz.* below).

section.title: ksb.org.quartz.*
section.para: Can be used to pass Quartz properties to the embedded Quartz scheduler. See the configuration documentation on the Quartz site. Essentially, any property prefixed with ksb.org.quartz. will have the "ksb." portion stripped and will be sent as configuration parameters to the embedded Quartz scheduler.

section.title: KSB Configurer Properties
section.para: In addition to the configuration parameters available in the KRice configuration system, the KSBConfigurer bean has some properties that can be injected to configure it:

section.title: exceptionMessagingScheduler
section.para: By default, the KSB uses an embedded Quartz scheduler for scheduling the retry of messages that fail to be sent. If desired, a Quartz scheduler can instead be injected into the KSBConfigurer and it will use that scheduler instead. See Quartz Scheduling for more detail.

section.title: messageDataSource
section.para: Specifies the javax.sql.DataSource to use for storing the asynchronous message queue. If not specified, this defaults to the DataSource injected into the RiceConfigurer.
If this DataSource is injected, then the registryDataSource must also be injected, and vice-versa.

section.title: registryDataSource
section.para: Specifies the javax.sql.DataSource to use for reading and writing from the Service Registry. If not specified, this defaults to the DataSource injected into the RiceConfigurer.
If this DataSource is injected, then the messageDataSource must also be injected, and vice-versa.
